intro: Chloraea cholilensis, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to yellow. The plant typically grows in high-altitude environments, often in rocky soils and alpine meadows. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in a fine pubescence, while its stems are erect and branching. Chloraea cholilensis is valued for its ornamental appeal and is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens.
